title: How to find the central idea of a poem - Quora

response.answer_text: Consider the title - it may give it all away in an instant, it often does. Examples would be Wordsworth’s, ‘Composed upon Westminster Bridge’, which is a sonnet meditation on the splendour of London town and the Thames flowing through it. Just a snippet: ‘This City now doth, like a garment, wear The beauty of the morning…’. And this also works for lyrics (sung poetry), eg ‘A Red, Red Rose’ by Robbie Burns. Just a snippet: ‘As fair art thou, my bonnie lass, So deep in luve am I.’ Of course we must first grasp the simile - the girl in question and and the new beauty of the rose are directly equated. Consider the first line - as in prose, it is often best to state the topic up front. Again from Burns: ‘O my Luve's like a red, red rose, That’s newly sprung in June;’. And a great favorite: ‘She walked in beauty like the night, of cloudy climes and starry skies…’, Keats. But both the title and the first line may play us false if we are overly hasty and overly literal. The title and first line of ‘The Sun Rising’, by John Donne - ‘Busy old fool, unruly sun, Why dost thou thus, Through windows, and through curtains call on us?’ Is not about the sun, it is about the intrusion onto the bliss of two lovers, woken up in bed by the early sun blinding in through the window. The poem runs on: ‘She's all states, and all princes, I, Nothing else is. Princes do but play us; compared to this, All honor's mimic, all wealth alchemy. Thou, sun, art half as happy as we…’. The Sun is personified in a metaphysical one-sided conversation, but the poem is all about their relationship. Then there is the omnific poem (as I call it), where we must consider the poem, the whole poem, and nothing but the poem. (That is, no silly cherry-picking from his autobiography to invent a meaning or theme.) The only way to capture the fish is to spread you net as wide and deep as possible, and many times at that. So, here is a great favourite by e. e. cummings, who would have been great friends with Douglas Adams, if only they had met. anyone lived in a pretty how town anyone lived in a pretty how town (with up so floating many bells down) spring summer autumn winter he sang his didn’t he danced his did. [first verse] ... ... someones married their everyones laughed their cryings and did their dance (sleep wake hope and then) they said their nevers they slept their dream ... Women and men (both dong and ding) summer autumn winter spring reaped their sowing and went their came sun moon stars rain [ends]
